description: George Todorovski is an artist, designer, director, writer and animator for film, television, games and comics, working on notable projects, such as Through The Wormhole, hosted by Morgan Freeman, Heavy Metal Magazine, Dungeon Crawler and the cult classic graphic novel series The Bear Stories.

description: Has only worked on The Bear Stories

description: Head designer for 2000AD, Judge Dredd Megazine, Solaris and Abaddon Books.
name: Simon Parr (PYE)

deck: Overton Loyd is a mass media artist most famous for his work with George Clinton and Parliament. He is a prolific creator who changes up his art style to fit whatever project he is currently working on.
description:
Career

Overton Loyd started his career as the house artist, costume, and stage designer for George Clinton and Parliament. He still tours with the band to this day, though his artistic career has branched out into fine art gallery showings and directing music videos. His latest contribution to the world of comics is the back cover of Harlan Ellison's Dream Corridor Special.
name: Overton Loyd

deck: Jane Mackenzie is a graphic artist and painter, mostly known for her science fiction work.
name: Jane Mackenzie

deck: Sam Raffa is a graphic designer and illustrator, mostly known for his science fiction illustrations.
name: Sam Raffa

deck: Craig Elliot is an American illustrator primarily known for his animated works at Disney and Dreamworks.
description:
Professional Career

Craig Elliot graduated from The Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, CA. He has since gone on to have a career as a motion picture animator for both Disney and Dreamworks, but he has had comics work produced from Dark Horse as well, including a story illustration in the first issue of Harlan Ellison's Dream Corridor.
name: Craig Elliot

deck: Artist for Heavy Metal Magazine, 2000 AD , Bluewater Comics and more..
name: Stefano Cardoselli

deck: Ron Brown is a multiple award winning science fiction and fantasy illustrator.
description:
Career

Ron Brown is primarily known as a storyboard illustrator and a science fiction and fantasy painter. He has worked for Disney TV, Nickelodeon, Warner Brothers, and Dark Horse Comics. His latest comics work is the cover of Harlan Ellison's Dream Corridor #5, and his self published comic, The Inside Out King.
name: Ron Brown

deck: Claudio Chiaverotti, born 6/20/1965 is an Italian comic book writer. He started writing texts for "Sturmtruppen" strips by Bonvi. Since 1989 is one of the authors of Dylan Dog.
name: Claudio Chiaverotti

deck: Dall'Agnol, born 9/10/1963, is an italian artist. He has worked for Sergio Bonelli Editore titles, such as Dylan Dog and Julia.
name: Pietro Dall'Agnol

deck: Cartoonist and illustrator for Secret Acres.
name: Joseph Lambert

deck: Luigi Mignacco is an italian author.
description: Luigi Mignacco, born 6/27/1960, is an italian author. He has worked for many italian comics such as Lanciostory and Topolino. Since 1986 he works for Sergio Bonelli Editore, where he has written stories for Miser No, Dylan Dog, Martin Mystère, Dampyr, and other titles.
name: Luigi Mignacco

description:
For 2000AD and the Judge Dredd Megazine, Steve has illustrated:

  • Bec and Kawl
  • Black Atlantic
  • Sinister Dexter
name: Steven Roberts

deck: Terry Bisson is a multiple award winning American science fiction and fantasy author. He has adapted many of his and others' written works to comics format.
description:
Career

Terry Bisson is a science fiction and fantasy author. He has won many awards for his written works, including the prestigious Hugo and Nebula awards. Bisson started writing comics for Creepy and Eerie magazines, before moving on to edit Web of Horror where he published some of the first professional work by comics luminaries like Bernie Wrightson and Michael Wm Kaluta. Bisson has adapted many written works for comics including stories by: Greg Bear, Anne McCaffrey, William Gibson, and most notably, the six part graphic novel adaptation of Roger Zelazny's Nine Princes In Amber for DC.
name: Terry Bisson

deck: Argentine cartoonist, illustrator and graphic designer.
name: Kwaichang Kraneo

deck: Owner of O-P-P Comics and artist.
name: Omaha Perez

deck: Kim Raymond is a UK artist who worked for DC Thomson and IPC in the 1980s
description: Kim Raymond started at DC Thomson (on girls title - Mandy). He also illustrated Judge Dredd (2000ad), Robo Machines (Eagle), Roy of the Rovers (Today Newspaper) and Checkout Girl (The Daily Star Newspaper).
name: Kim Raymond

description: British artist who has illustrated stories for Super Naturals comic, as well as Eagle and 2000ad.
name: Alan Langford

description: Illustrated a handful of stories for the early issues of 2000AD.
name: Jim Eldridge

deck: Competition winner - scripted one episode of Hap Hazzard.
description: Hap Hazzard was created by Steve Dillon and first appeared in Prog 561 of 2000AD in 1988. Dillon wrote and drew all six subsequent appearances of Hazzard. His final appearance (to date) in Prog 1164 was actually scripted by Hayden Nash, the winner of a competition run by 2000AD at the Comics '99 festival and for readers of Comics International magazine.
name: Hayden Nash

description: Now defunct digital media company.
name: Cool Beans Productions

deck: Carlo Ambrosini is an italian artist. He works mainly for Sergio Bonelli Editore, where he has penciled, among others, Ken Parker, Tex and Dylan Dog. He is also co-creator of Bonelli character Napoleone.
name: Carlo Ambrosini

deck: Lou Harrison is a painter who has done work for DC, Marvel and Dark Horse Comics.
description:
Career

Lou Harrison has painted many covers for Marvel and DC, including most notably, the covers for Roger Zelazny's Nine Princes in Amber.
name: Lou Harrison

deck: Italian artist, Ticci is one of the authors of Tex.
name: Giovanni Ticci

deck: Bryn Barnard is an American painter and mixed media artist.
description:
Career

Bryn Barnard is primarily a science fiction and fantasy painter. His most noteworthy work to date has been mixing his painting skills with children's education. He rarely works in the field of comics, however he was the interior artist on one issue of Roger Zelazny's Nine Princes in Amber comic adaptation.
name: Bryn Barnard

deck: Gianluigi Coppola is an italian artist. For Sergio Bonelli Editore has penciled some Dylan Dog and Martin Mystere issues
name: Gianluigi Coppola

name: Warren Spector

description: Audrey Anthony "Toni" Blum Bossert was a Eisner & Iger Shop Comic Book Writer who scripted many of the early Fox comics of the Golden Age. She was also the daughter of comics artist Alex Blum and the wife of comics artist Bill Bossert.
name: Audrey Blum

deck: Born and raised in New Jersey, Michael Uslan was a comic book fan from an early age. In college, he made history by starting the first accredited course on comic book history. He later succeeded in Hollywood by producing such films as "Swamp Thing" and the Batman films.
description:
Early Life

Mike Uslan grew up in Deal Park, New Jersey. His older brother, Paul, first introduced him to comic books and he quickly became a fanatic, attaining a collection of over 30,000 comics by the time he graduated high school.

Although he grew up in a time when Frederick Wertham lead the nation in a fear-based crusade against comic books, his parents didn't buy into the hype and allowed him to keep his collection. He developed a love for Batman, and when it was announced that there would be a Batman television series on ABC, he was understandably excited. However, when the show premiered on January 12, 1966, he was mortified. His favorite character had become a joke, a victim of the campy culture of the 60's. From that day forward, Uslan promised to bring a dark, serious Batman to the silver screen, returning the character to his roots.

College, DC Comics and the Journey to Hollywood

Uslan attended Indiana University. The school was accepting course ideas from students at the time. If any student could get a member of the staff to back their concept, they could pitch to a board consisting of the dean and several professors to get the course accredited. He had the idea to pitch a course on comic book history.

With his long hair, love beads and Spider-Man t-shirt, Uslan marched in, met with the dean, who looked at him with utter disdain and said, "So you're the one who wants to have a course on funny books?"

Michael continued with his pitch, unshaken by the deans comment. He spoke passionately, telling the dean that comic books were a full-blown mythology. The Greeks called him Hermes, the Romans called him Mercury, we call him the Flash. The Greeks called him Poseidon, the Romans called him Neptune, we call him Aquaman. By the time he finished, he had won over the dean, who confessed that he was a fan of Superman as a boy. He quickly made history, starting the first fully accredited college course on comics.

While he was in college, he began working at DC Comics under Sol Harrsion, then-president of DC.

After he graduated college, Uslan got right on the trail to achieving his dream of getting work in Hollywood and eventually making a serious Batman film, but he found it harder then he thought. He realized that his only option was to go to law school and work for an entertainment law firm to understand the business end of film making.

Although he hated every minute he was in law school, Michael continued through it, knowing it was either this or giving up on his dream. He continued to work at DC, and even got the opportunity to step in for Denny O'Neil and write an issue of The Shadow, which he came up with on the spot.

Shortly after his first comic book script was published, he was approached by Julie Schwarts who gave Uslan a great honor by telling him that his script did not, in fact, stink. Schwarts offered Uslan and opportunity to write Batman and he graciously accepted.

Uslan graduated from law school, worked at an entertainment firm for four years, then began making regular trips to Hollywood from his home in New Jersey in order to pitch his Batman film to every producer in the business. Unfortunately, they all slammed their doors in his face. The campy 60's image had become more ingrained in people's minds than he thought. No one wanted a dark, serious comic book movie, ESPECIALLY not one involving Batman. After 10 long years, fighting Hollywood every step of the way, Michael Uslan finally got to sit down in a theater and watch his dream come to life. Tim Burton's 1989 film, Batman, shattered box office records and became a world wide phenomenon. Uslan had finally won over the world, and Batman got his chance to shine.

Memoir

Michael Uslan published his memoir, The Boy Who Loved Batman, in 2010. It has recieved critical acclaim from both comic book fans and people who have never read a comic in their lives. He continues to speak at conventions and other events, sharing his experience and his philosophy with people, advising them to follow their dreams, and not be a "coulda been".
name: Michael Uslan

deck: Refered to as the most prolific european comicbook artist, he has worked for over 60 years in characters like Bob Morane, Signor Spaghetti, Johnny Goodbye, Modeste et Pompon, etc etc
name: Dino Attanasio

deck: Belgian writer, created Bob Morane in 1953. He has written over 200 adventures novels and adapted some of them for the comicbook versions.

name: Coria

deck: Colorist in Bob Morane and XIII. Married with William Vance.
